ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This is the best class I have taken at FES.

The professor was very responsive to students. I think some students felt that his feedback did not always create a supportive learning environment. I do not know if this was a common feeling. I only heard it from one student. Discussion over what makes something good writing should happen in this class but not at the cost of making someone feel stupid (inadvertently).

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I learned how to write effectively, and I learned to be confident in my writing.
The ability to write about whatever we wanted each week and hearing other students' work.
The intimate setting of the class.

I thought that each class was well thought out and very useful. I liked the rhythm we had in each class and the consistent format. The few simple exercises of reviewing sentences and written pieces were very informative.
Verlyn is a wonderful teacher, just getting to sit around and listen to him for three hours each week was the best thing ever.
The space to write, and to discuss writing -- broadly or narrowly, academic or personal, descriptive or narrative -- is a breath of fresh air in a school that otherwise only values academic texts.
The class became a very tight group at the end of the semester because we learned with, from and about each other which I have not experienced in any other course.
Verlyn's wisdom, Verlyn's feedback on written work, the demand to consistently produce quality work, the readings, peer feedback

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: A little more time spent on what might not actually be accepted in certain contexts outside of the class (e.g. using contractions in a cover letter). I feel a little confused now about when and where it is okay for me to have more of a creative license and when and where I should stick to the rules for the sake of professionalism.

I don't think anything needs to be improved. There were a few weeks at the end when I might've liked more reading. But that just give me more time to focus on my classmates work. It was actually really nice to look more critically at what they had written.

It would be helpful if the professor could follow the rules of constructive criticism. I know he feels strongly about the subject, but everyone in the class already knows how good he is and is in constant awe about it, so there is no need to emphasize that gap.
The Saturday deadline for writing was a challenge. If the deadline could be moved to Sunday, I imagine students would greatly appreciate it.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Work shopping bad sentences every week was helpful. Reading pieces from certain authors was also useful.
See above (for the beginning of the course) that improved in many ways at the end of it. The professor offered help and consolation at many points, which was very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course isn't about filling an incredibly functional role in your graduate school experience. It's all about writing prose which is not something we often do in our studies. That said, I've taken lots of lessons from this course for simply writing emails, letters and even occasionally policy papers.
This course focused on improving my writing, which will help in all of my other coursework. I feel that I have the tools to carry on improving my own writing.
I liked learning from the given literature and his comments throughout the course. A more stringent course structure is in my opinion not needed.
I'm a better writer, a better communicator, and a better editor after this course. All of those skills will be invaluable in my ministry. I will be writing regularly throughout my career.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was always told I was a good writer until a professor reviewed one of my papers last spring. It was a wake up call. My writing had worsened and I wanted a chance to go back to the basics. The class also gave me the chance to gain confidence in my own thoughts.
I wanted to improve my writing and analysis abilities.

I took this course because I wanted something different this semester. I wanted a course that was gonna build general skills not just skills in a particular topic area. I was taking quite a few research credits and so this was a nice way to balance out the quantitative work I was doing. You get into a rhythm of writing every week, which is really nice.
I wanted to improve my writing.

I wanted to be able to write about a growing list of topics of interest that didn't have other places within my course load. Unfortunately, I never left myself enough time to write in a focused (and short) manner about this list. Really important in this class to leave enough time to write, walk away from your writing, and return (at least once) before handing it in.
I wanted to improve my writing and learn how to enjoy writing again.
To bring together my professional formation for ministry and my love of the natural world and to do so through writing.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
I do feel that my writing became clearer and more understandable. I've learned to trust the reader more, and I don't feel like I'm writing to middle school students anymore.
Yes, I feel that my prose is much more succinct and readable.
Yes, very much.
Yes. They were, in fact, exceeded.
I learned and grew more in this course than I expected and hoped for.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take this class, no matter what your focus. It is the most valuable course I've taken at Yale.

It is not a writing course that teaches you how to write press releases or something specific. It is a chance to make your writing more clear and thoughtful by getting rid of jargon and the ideas of what we think intelligent writing sounds like.

Just know that you're not going to get a publication out of it or an entirely cleaned piece of writing. But it is going to improve the process through which you approach writing and it will suggest many editing techniques to strengthen your voice.
Do it. This will be one of my favorite courses of all times.

Learn from your fellow students as much as from the professor. The biggest strength of this course is the fellowship of an incredible and motivated group of people that is then fueled by an incredibly intelligent and eloquent professor.
Be prepared to work. Be prepared to want to work. The format of the class will make you want to put in consistent and significant effort each week.
